message: Oh. Well.
like an animated transition?

Ok, so I have a span within an a tag. I need it to go from having no background, to having a background gradient on hover. Can I do this and if so can you give me working example? I've been banging my head on this for awhile now.
You want the <a> to go between having and not having a background gradient? or the span?

Can't find proof of this, but not sure you can put a background img on a span cause it's inline.  Try setting the span as "display: block" to check.
• Stuff Words
Sorry to hit and run, but I'm walking out the door. Would like to see the finished product tho, nice idea.
actual color values aren't important at this point, thats easily swappable

Some stuff and some other stuff a { display: block; /* Or else it's just an inline element */ width: 100px; height: 100px; } a span { background: transparent; } a:hover span { /* if this later browsers, you could :hover the span */ background: #efefef /* bg fallback for crappy browsers */ background: -webkit-gradient(linear, left top, left bottom, from(#fff), to(#efefef)); background: -moz-linear-gradient(top, #fff, #efefef); filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorstr='#fff', endColorstr='#efefef'); }
gah
yeah
is this text?
bingo
cool. easy

Some stuff and some other stuff a { display: block; width: 100px; height: 100px; } a span { background: transparent; -webkit-transition-property: background; -webkit-transition-duration: 2s; } a:hover span { background: #efefef; background: -webkit-gradient(linear, left top, left bottom, from(#fff), to(#efefef)); background: -moz-linear-gradient(top, #fff, #efefef); filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.gradient(startColorstr='#fff', endColorstr='#efefef'); }

not that there's anything officially to support, so, yeah.

@ianshea makes me wonder what exactly the spec is referring to when they say that transitions can be done with "background-image (gradients only)". having trouble finding an understandable explanation.
@ericzanol Yeah... The 'spec' and 'webkit-' and 'moz' are all a little different. Makes working with CSS3 quite frustrating.

@thesethery That technique from cibgraphics is probably what you're going to have to use. The problem with the CSS3 gradient ( in webkit at least ) is that the gradient is created and treated as an image. http://developer.apple.com/library/safari/#documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariCSSRef/Articles/Functions.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40007955-SW26
@ianshea i assume that the browsers just haven't fully supported it yet. guess that's not so hard to understand.
